subject: Physics
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course/subject?

Growing up, there was always this unspoken idea that physics wasn't really 'for girls'. That impression came from the names we were taught, and even the cartoon figures in textbooks. The word 'scientist' automatically evoked the image of a man in a lab coat, and for a long time I assumed it didn't hold a space for me. That changed when I visited the Marie Curie Museum in Paris. I was amazed to learn that some of her notes remain so radioactive they must be stored in lead lined boxes. Seeing her legacy up close challenged the image of scientists I'd grown up with and made me question why I had ever doubted that I could belong in physics too.
Following this, I began exploring topics I had once deemed daunting, such as nuclear fusion, particularly its potential as a future energy source. Projects like ITER aim to replicate the Sun's energy generating processes on Earth. In a Nuclear Physics Masterclass, I learnt that 1kg of deuterium and 1.5kg of tritium can release 850TJ of energy, illustrating the scale of this breakthrough. In a world still very reliant on non-renewables, I find the physics behind fusion vitally socially significant. Exploring topics like this deepened my appreciation for how physics tackles global challenges, and that's what inspires me to study it further.


How have your qualifications & studies helped you to prepare for this course/subject?

Reading Carl Sagan's Cosmos sparked my fascination with the complexity of our universe. <a certain topic> 

I was especially drawn to… 

Curious about the mathematical structure behind physics, I read In Pursuit of the Unknown by Ian Stewart. This book revealed how calculus isn't just a mathematical tool, but also <i'll read 2-3 chps>

My interest in the fundamental structure of matter led me to complete CERN's particle physics course. I was especially intrigued by the Standard Model of Particle Physics, the way elementary particles can be grouped by charge and mass, yet only the first generation makes up the stable matter we encounter daily. The heavier second and third generations appear solely in high energy environments, and decay swiftly into first generation particles. Despite their fleeting existence, the reason why nature requires exactly three generations remains a major unsolved question. The course also introduced me to the practical side of physics, explaining that alpha particles — which have low penetration power, can be detected in cloud chambers due to the small amount of radioactive radon present in air. The connection between particle physics and chemistry highlights the importance of drawing knowledge from scientific disciplines, rather than viewing them in isolation, as many phenomena rely on an interplay between fields.
 

<<I also took part in It All Adds Up, run by the Mathematical Institute at the University of Oxford, where I completed MAT questions that deepened my appreciation for the diverse approaches to solving a single question. One of the most memorable sessions was an origami workshop. Folding a piece of paper repeatedly from different directions so that its edge met a fixed central point produced a series of creases acting as tangents to a parabola, revealing a quadratic curve. The unexpected links between geometry and the physical world fascinated me.>>
Additionally, to strengthen my comprehension in the field of mathematics, I took part in the UKMT Senior Maths Challenge. Preparing for it developed my problem solving skills as most questions required pattern recognition rather than memorised methods.
This further encouraged me to partake in STEM SMART on Isaac Physics, working through progressively difficult questions sharpened my ability to apply mathematical techniques in unfamiliar contexts. Something I now enjoy, rather than find intimidating.

Furthermore, I 

Attending 'The Beauty of Falling' at Imperial College introduced me to Einstein's general relativity and how it predicts its own failure, as the observed rate of cosmic expansion is slower than predictions based on vacuum energy. This raised the possibility that gravity is finite in range. Another idea that fascinated me was how gravitational waves carry traces of everything they pass through, thus detecting them can help us understand the universe's composition. 


What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?

During my work experience at the Mullard Space Science Laboratory, run by UCL, our group designed a spacecraft for a mission to explore the magnetosphere. In order to sell our mission to the PHD students, we managed to stay well within budget, conducted a risk assessment, researched the effects of solar wind on satellites—including potential damage to electronics and communication interference, and discovered how launching near the equator provides a speed boost due to the Earth's rotation. This experience improved my ability to work collaboratively and manage time effectively. Working together to explore these topics helped me connect theoretical physics with real world space missions. 
Another part of the placement involved learning to solder electronic components. This hands on task gave me a deeper appreciation for the level of precision required in technical work and sharpened my attention to detail.

As a prefect, I've developed my leadership skills and improved my discipline.
I'm also a self taught Guzheng player, being able to de-stress through music is a privilege that has helped me maintain balance alongside the rigorous academic demands. I have also gained resilience, and the ability to obtain knowledge independently, a skill which prepares me for the need of self learning in university.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Growing up, there was always this unspoken idea that physics wasn't really 'for girls'...That changed when I visited the Marie Curie Museum in Paris
feedback_items.your_feedback: This entire first paragraph reads too much like a story about Marie Curie and women in STEM. It's too narrative and rudimentary for Imperial or Oxford physics. You need to get straight into the physics instead of telling a personal story.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start with 'I became interested in physics because of this book, article, or lecture' and then explain the theory you learned about. Choose something beyond A-level that shows genuine academic interest.

feedback_items.weak_passage: such as nuclear fusion, particularly its potential as a future energy source. Projects like ITER aim to replicate the Sun's energy generating processes
feedback_items.your_feedback: Nuclear fusion is kind of a process rather than a deep theoretical topic. You've tried to link it to renewables, but the topic choice is questionable - it's not academically interesting enough and there's only so much you can go with it. Choose topics that are more theoretically interesting in their own right.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Look at your potential tutors' CVs and see what areas they're studying. Choose topics that are more widely interesting in the field of physics, not just processes or applications.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My interest in the fundamental structure of matter led me to complete CERN's particle physics course
feedback_items.your_feedback: The phrase 'fundamental structure of matter' seems very inauthentic because that's not really anything specific. Nobody says they're interested in the fundamental structure of matter unless they're going to explain that properly. Your topic choices here and with nuclear fusion are poor - they're used in explanation of something else rather than being interesting in their own accord.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose topics that are complete and interesting as standalone subjects, not just supporting examples for other points. Make sure your interest statements sound genuine and specific.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I also took part in It All Adds Up, run by the Mathematical Institute at the University of Oxford...UKMT Senior Maths Challenge...STEM SMART on Isaac Physics
feedback_items.your_feedback: The whole section reads like a list - problem solving, STEM SMART, etc. You're just naming activities without developing ideas. The sentence about 'something I now enjoy rather than find intimidating' is unnecessary - they know the level of difficulty for students.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand the parabola idea from the origami workshop to something more interesting. Remove or consolidate the repetitive mentions of problem-solving and pattern recognition. If including Isaac Physics or UKMT, either put it in your reference or briefly mention it without wasting characters on generic descriptions.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Preparing for it developed my problem solving skills as most questions required pattern recognition rather than memorised methods. This further encouraged me to partake in STEM SMART
feedback_items.your_feedback: This description is really not very useful at all and is just a waste of characters. Either include specific examples from Isaac Physics or just list it off briefly, but the way you've included it here adds no value.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut the generic descriptions and either expand with a specific example from Isaac Physics or mention it very briefly without elaborating on obvious skills.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Attending 'The Beauty of Falling' at Imperial College introduced me to Einstein's general relativity and how it predicts its own failure
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: This should come at the top of your statement along with the MI stuff. Lead with strong academic content like this.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Attending 'The Beauty of Falling' at Imperial College introduced me to Einstein's general relativity and how it predicts its own failure, as the observed rate of cosmic expansion is slower than predictions based on vacuum energy. This raised the possibility that gravity is finite in range. Another idea that fascinated me was how gravitational waves carry traces of everything they pass through
feedback_items.why_strong: This is your best section so far because it's the most academic, to the point, and focused on your subject area. The structure works: here is something I saw, here is what it's about, here is what I find interesting, here is where it took me next. You can clearly write at the right level when you focus on academic content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This experience improved my ability to work collaboratively and manage time effectively. Working together to explore these topics helped me connect theoretical physics with real world space missions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: These last few sentences are things I would already have inferred from you doing this project - I already know you can work collaboratively. These sentences should be replaced with more explanation of the science of how you designed the spacecraft or anything interesting about the spacecraft itself.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the generic claims about skills gained and instead explain more of the technical details - what went into the spacecraft design, interesting challenges you faced, specific physics principles you applied.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Another part of the placement involved learning to solder electronic components. This hands on task gave me a deeper appreciation for the level of precision required in technical work and sharpened my attention to detail.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The sentence about this being a hands-on task is useless. The soldering section isn't really physics, so you can just cut these last few sentences entirely.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut this section and potentially bring in something else related to physics to use the space more effectively.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This needs a fair amount of work and is one of the lesser finished drafts. The first paragraph needs to be completely rewritten to focus on physics rather than storytelling. The structure overall is messy - your strongest content (Beauty of Falling) is buried at the end when it should lead. Topic choices in the middle section are questionable and lack depth.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Restructure: Start with Beauty of Falling and MI content. Cut the Marie Curie story entirely or reduce to one sentence. Choose better physics topics that show theoretical depth. Expand academic explanations throughout. Remove generic skill descriptions and focus on technical details of what you actually learned and did.

subject: Economics and Management
statement_full_text:
Reading "Money in One Lesson" (Jackson) first introduced me to behavioural economics; money described as a "shared fiction" revealed to me the place of psychology in shaping our economic systems. This introduced me to prospect theory, and I analysed this more deeply at a summer school, where I was introduced to a case study about "abunu" - the sharecropping contracts that Ghanaian cocoa farmers agree to. Rationally, it would be optimal to accept a fixed-rate contract. However, they give up half of their yield, avoiding the greater perceived risk of paying fixed rent after a lackluster harvest, outweighing the potential gain of keeping more; displaying a loss averse mindset. Though Marshall's neoclassical model of sharecropping can indicate an optimal price to set for a fixed rent rate, the persistence of these contracts highlight that neoclassical assumptions like complete information or utility-maximisation do not tell the full story of our economic activity. This further cemented my appreciation for economics - behavioural economics offers the psychological depth where neoclassical models fall short. This contrast of balancing predictable economic models against nuanced economic agents entices me to study the subject at degree level.

I attended a land economy taster session, where I was introduced to the idea of urban renewal and the complex intersection of climate change, gentrification, and economic development in cities. This interested me in the economics involved in addressing climate change, so I read Jason Hickel's article on degrowth which challenged the contemporary economic thought of growth as the goal. While I agree that climate change cannot be addressed without rethinking economic priorities, I find the global mentality shift degrowth requires too stark for politicians to propose and citizens to accept - especially given the media-driven state of politics, where GDP acts as a scoreboard. It's for that reason I see it as extremely ambitious, even despite its merits. In the Kavita Singh PPE Essay Competition, I argued that economies should instead implement services as their main drivers of economic growth in the long-term, an idea I read about in an article from LSE. This reduces material throughput without compromising economic growth, allowing for innovation led solutions like new technology. To explore behavioural economics, I created an academic poster on the effects of Buy Now Pay Later schemes on Gen Z consumers, as part of Cambridge's Lucy Cavendish AAP. I looked at how the lack of background checks and the frictionless nature of using services like Clearpay or Klarna exploit cognitive biases - particularly choice architecture and availability bias. Through research, I examined how these behavioural nudges mask the true cost of credit, leading to overconsumption and an increase in debt. I argued that this will create a market failure rooted in asymmetric information in the long term if there isn't more regulation. This project made me appreciate policy intervention which protects vulnerable consumers, undermining the neoclassical assumption of the rational, utility-maximising consumer.

Reading "Factfulness" (Rosling) sharpened my data analysis and interpretation skills and challenged my personal biases regarding the world. I particularly liked when he talked about sensationalism, and to always consider if an equivalent positive event would be reported the same way a negative event is. As Deputy Head Boy, I've worked collaboratively on projects like charity events, equipping me with skills like persistence and patience, crucial for the rigorous nature of undergraduate research. Working in retail has also given me a first-hand lens on consumer behaviour, particularly pricing strategies and product placement.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall this is really strong, especially for a first draft with no support. One of the better statements reviewed. The nudge section is particularly excellent and should be your standard for the rest of the statement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Mirror the quality and structure of your BNPL nudge paragraph throughout the rest of the statement. Focus on the first couple of paragraphs which need the most work.
feedback_items.strong_passage: To explore behavioural economics, I created an academic poster on the effects of Buy Now Pay Later schemes on Gen Z consumers...I looked at how the lack of background checks and the frictionless nature of using services like Clearpay or Klarna exploit cognitive biases - particularly choice architecture and availability bias...I argued that this will create a market failure rooted in asymmetric information
feedback_items.why_strong: This section is really excellent with perfect structure: you identify the behavioral economics topic, explain your research methodology, discuss the cognitive biases involved, connect to theory about market failure, and draw meaningful conclusions. This is exactly the right way to develop an idea in a personal statement.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Reading "Money in One Lesson" (Jackson)
feedback_items.your_feedback: Don't put the author's name in brackets like that. You should write the full name properly.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change to: 'Reading Gavin Jackson's Money in One Lesson' or use the author's full name without brackets.

feedback_items.weak_passage: revealed to me the place of psychology in shaping our economic systems
feedback_items.your_feedback: You say it revealed the place of psychology but you don't actually tell me what that place is. Not all of us are going to think the same - this is your conclusion and insight, so you need to explain it. You then move to prospect theory but don't explain what it is.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain specifically what role you think psychology plays in economic systems. Briefly define prospect theory before discussing the case study.

feedback_items.weak_passage: However, they give up half of their yield, avoiding the greater perceived risk of paying fixed rent after a lackluster harvest, outweighing the potential gain of keeping more; displaying a loss averse mindset
feedback_items.your_feedback: This paragraph is too long and you're overexplaining something that's not as complex as the number of words you've used. The middle section explaining the farmers' behavior could be much more concise.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Simplify to: 'Despite it being optimal to accept a fixed-rate contract, farmers show a loss averse mindset' - that's enough for readers to understand your point without the lengthy explanation.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This further cemented my appreciation for economics - behavioural economics offers the psychological depth where neoclassical models fall short
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is both a bold claim and an underdeveloped one. Consider either putting something else here or taking it out entirely.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either remove this sentence or develop it with specific examples of how behavioral economics provides depth that neoclassical models lack.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This contrast of balancing predictable economic models against nuanced economic agents entices me to study the subject at degree level
feedback_items.your_feedback: This reads like a summary sentence and is unnecessary. We don't want to waste time on intro summaries - we want to spend more time developing ideas. The tutor already got that you want to study economics from your detailed explanation in the first paragraph.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this conclusion sentence entirely. Instead link to another example or reading that extends your point about behavioral economics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I attended a land economy taster session, where I was introduced to the idea of urban renewal and the complex intersection of climate change, gentrification, and economic development in cities
feedback_items.your_feedback: This introduction is a bit list-like. It would be better to keep this shorter because the expansion about addressing climate change and degrowth is much more interesting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Shorten the land economy taster introduction to get more quickly to your analysis of degrowth.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I find the global mentality shift degrowth requires too stark for politicians to propose and citizens to accept - especially given the media-driven state of politics, where GDP acts as a scoreboard
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is quite a PPE-type conclusion focused on politics and media, which is less economicsy. The conclusion you drew is interesting but not quite right for an economics statement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change this to a more economic conclusion from the same topic - focus on economic mechanisms, incentives, or models rather than political feasibility.

feedback_items.weak_passage: It's for that reason I see it as extremely ambitious, even despite its merits
feedback_items.your_feedback: This sentence is filler and a bit fluffy - it doesn't add substantive analysis.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this sentence to make space for more substantive economic analysis.

feedback_items.weak_passage: economies should instead implement services as their main drivers of economic growth in the long-term, an idea I read about in an article from LSE
feedback_items.your_feedback: You say 'instead' but you didn't tell me what this is as opposed to. You also don't explain what you mean by implementing services as drivers of economic growth. Don't cite 'an article from LSE' - quote the actual writer.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain specifically how services can drive economic growth versus other approaches. Cite the specific author rather than just the institution. Give a concrete example of the innovation or new technology you mention.

feedback_items.weak_passage: As Deputy Head Boy, I've worked collaboratively on projects like charity events, equipping me with skills like persistence and patience, crucial for the rigorous nature of undergraduate research
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're telling me you have persistence and patience, but I can already know that by you having worked on projects. Don't feel the need to spell out obvious skills - it wastes space.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this sentence to give more space to talk about academic topics elsewhere in your statement.

subject: Medicine
statement_full_text:
Instead of heading straight home after primary school, I often spent time on the university campus where my mother taught physiotherapy. What began as peering into any microscope I encountered in her staff room soon deepened when I peeked at her lessons. I vividly remember the sharp scent that filled the room as I looked at the preserved body she used for her demonstration. I watched her point out and elaborate on each muscle, tendon, and bone I had never even realised was also a part of me. For me, what might usually be considered an unsettling sight became an early step into medicine.

During a heart dissection in Biology, I became interested in cardiovascular health, which inspired my initial EPQ research idea on cardiac embolism. Though I changed my research question later, reading various articles made me appreciate how scientific knowledge can be translated into clinical practice, as it had proved invaluable when shadowing a pharmacist. I learn about treatment plans for patients with cardiac embolism and could follow discussions confidently, as I had built a basic foundation on cardiovascular health.

The EPQ I ultimately completed focused on dreams through both biological and psychological perspectives. This project strengthened my ability to conduct independent research, source credible material, and critically analyse it. It improved my written and verbal communication, and strengthened my organisation and time management as I balanced it with my A levels. My Psychology studies also gave me a good understanding of research ethics and structuring interviews, which helped me conduct my own primary research for my EPQ ethically and efficiently.

In addition, completing online courses on OpenLearn learn such as Metals in Medicine, extended my A-level chemistry knowledge by applying it to medicine. I linked it to when I shadowed a gastroenterologist and radiologist working together. I observed the metal-based contrast agents and MRI used to assess a patient's recovery after gallbladder surgery. The course deepened my understanding of how chemistry principles, such as H NMR, underpin diagnostic imaging, showing why keeping up with advancing technology is vital to providing a quicker and more accurate diagnosis to patients.

During my work experience at the Lister Hospital, I saw how effective patient care relied on collaboration between multiple departments. It showed me how every healthcare role plays an integral part in a patient's recovery, from their diagnosis to discharge. They communicated and adapted to each patient's needs even during odd and stressful situations. It taught me that good medical practice is not based solely on clinical expertise but on listening, communicating, and working cohesively.

I volunteered at the British Heart Foundation Charity Shop to further develop these skills. Working with a diverse team taught me effective communication and cooperation while improving my ability to show empathy and confidence when interacting with people from different backgrounds.

Furthermore, I plan to use my gap year to gain more hands-on experience and help strengthen my interpersonal skills. I have joined BEfriend, which supports people experiencing loneliness for various reasons. This will help me learn to communicate sensitively and build trust with individuals in vulnerable situations, which I observed is an essential skill in healthcare. I also intend to seek part-time employment in a healthcare setting to continue to learn from patient interactions and the truth about practising medicine.

Outside of academics, I enjoy learning languages like Hindi and Kannada to stay fluent, and I also play the guitar, create art, and crochet. These hobbies give me balance, patience, and creativity, qualities I believe are just as valuable in medicine as scientific understanding.

Following this career path will be hard but also personally fulfilling. I know that my attributes of hard work, dedication, and eagerness to learn will help me prosper in medicine.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Considering you've just moved countries, you've done pretty well. However, the biggest issue is that it reads like a summary - not getting enough development or specific detail. It's lacking academic content throughout.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add more specific academic content - what you actually learned, theories you studied, detailed explanations of your research. Focus less on listing activities and more on demonstrating deep understanding of medical concepts.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Instead of heading straight home after primary school, I often spent time on the university campus where my mother taught physiotherapy. What began as peering into any microscope I encountered in her staff room soon deepened when I peeked at her lessons. I vividly remember the sharp scent that filled the room
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is written like fiction - like a story with 'sharp scent' and 'heading straight home'. This is not an English writing exercise. Every character counts in a personal statement. This should have been one sentence: 'My physiotherapist mother inspired me to take an interest in medicine from an early age.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reduce the entire opening to one concise sentence. Remove all the narrative details and get straight to the point.

feedback_items.weak_passage: During a heart dissection in Biology, I became interested in cardiovascular health, which inspired my initial EPQ research idea on cardiac embolism. Though I changed my research question later
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't need this first sentence or the process of how you changed your EPQ. You're wasting words explaining what you didn't do. This whole section should just be about an article or book you read, not the story of your EPQ journey.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut the entire process description. Link to an article or book instead of the EPQ. Just say what you actually did, not what you initially planned or changed.

feedback_items.weak_passage: reading various articles made me appreciate how scientific knowledge can be translated into clinical practice, as it had proved invaluable when shadowing a pharmacist. I learn about treatment plans for patients with cardiac embolism and could follow discussions confidently, as I had built a basic foundation on cardiovascular health
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is just a summary and is basically useless. You haven't told me your understanding of cardiovascular health, you didn't mention a specific article, you didn't explain how it translates to clinical practice, you haven't told me the scientific knowledge. I would love to know what you actually did and learned.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain specific cardiovascular concepts you learned. Name actual articles. Describe the treatment plans you observed. Give concrete examples of the scientific knowledge you gained.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The EPQ I ultimately completed focused on dreams through both biological and psychological perspectives
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is very vague and difficult to follow. You should give your actual EPQ title instead of this unclear description.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: State your exact EPQ title rather than this vague description.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This project strengthened my ability to conduct independent research, source credible material, and critically analyse it. It improved my written and verbal communication, and strengthened my organisation and time management
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're just listing generic skills instead of telling me what you actually did. They know what you do in an EPQ - that part doesn't need to be repeated. You need to tell them what you specifically did in your EPQ.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Describe your EPQ using: What was it? What was your argument/methodology (surveys, etc.)? What was your conclusion? What sources did you use? Remove the generic skills list entirely.

feedback_items.weak_passage: completing online courses on OpenLearn learn such as Metals in Medicine, extended my A-level chemistry knowledge by applying it to medicine. I linked it to when I shadowed a gastroenterologist and radiologist working together
feedback_items.your_feedback: This part is fairly okay - at least you've listed real courses. It would be great to know more about what knowledge you actually gained, something more academic, but there are more problematic parts to fix first.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add one more sentence explaining specific chemistry knowledge you gained from the course and how it connects to the diagnostic imaging you observed.

feedback_items.weak_passage: During my work experience at the Lister Hospital, I saw how effective patient care relied on collaboration between multiple departments...They communicated and adapted to each patient's needs...good medical practice is not based solely on clinical expertise but on listening, communicating, and working cohesively
feedback_items.your_feedback: This section is repetitive and list-like. You mention 'communicated and adapted', 'listening communicating working cohesively', 'collaboration', 'integral role' multiple times. The same concepts keep appearing - it's a waste of characters.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consolidate these repetitive points about communication and teamwork into fewer sentences to free up space for academic content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I volunteered at the British Heart Foundation Charity Shop to further develop these skills. Working with a diverse team taught me effective communication and cooperation while improving my ability to show empathy and confidence
feedback_items.your_feedback: If you're over the character count, this would be the section to remove. It only mentions communication and cooperation, which you've already established multiple times in the previous paragraph.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut this entire paragraph as it's redundant and doesn't add new information beyond what you've already communicated.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Furthermore, I plan to use my gap year to gain more hands-on experience and help strengthen my interpersonal skills. I have joined BEfriend, which supports people experiencing loneliness for various reasons. This will help me learn to communicate sensitively and build trust
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're overusing 'communicate' throughout this statement - such a waste. This is too much explanation of what you're going to be doing throughout the year without enough focus on what you're going to be studying to keep academic knowledge fresh.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of listing future activities, explain how you plan to keep academic knowledge fresh - what you'll be reading, studying, or researching during your gap year.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Outside of academics, I enjoy learning languages like Hindi and Kannada to stay fluent, and I also play the guitar, create art, and crochet
feedback_items.your_feedback: This outro is fine. Many students like to include this type of conclusion.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: After cutting the suggested sections, if you have space left, add one academic section - an article about medicine and something you learned, or a theory you find interesting.

feedback_items.your_feedback: If you don't have time to change it, that's fine. Just be aware of these issues for interviews - know what the admissions officer is likely thinking as they read this.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be prepared to discuss in depth the medical concepts and experiences you mention, especially the EPQ and work experience, as interviewers will expect detailed knowledge beyond the summary you've provided.

subject: Computer Science
statement_full_text:
My application for Computer Science is motivated by how broad the field is, with the fascinating but forgotten interplay of policy and technology being a captivating point. The political impact of AI with its mainstream and commercial success, alongside the interwoven impacts AI has on surveillance, education, and community, are some of the many reasons I love this subject.

My interest in technology stems from my parents' retail job becoming increasingly automated, which led me to read 'An Introduction to Automation and Artificial Intelligence', which introduced me to the multi-faceted approach companies take towards managing self-sufficient technology with the 'automation spectrum'. This is useful in deciding the risks of automated technology as Professor Parr expresses how development of automated technologies takes place more within the commercial world than the military division due to potential risks, a concept which is also built in the TEDx Talk 'The ethical dilemma we face on AI and autonomous tech'. In the talk, Christane Fox expresses the huge risk with military technology being unable to discern between 'combatants and civilians' on the battlefield, showing the same issue with autonomous cars struggling to choose between 'pedestrians' and a 'brick wall' in situations where harm and ethical thought is required. The inability of AI to hold concept of ethical thought and enact with the morals of a human being led me to question how far AI models can mimic human morals and ethics. Through my research, I found 'The Turing Test', an article published by Stanford which explores the test made to measure 'human intelligence' within machines, using the 'Imitation Game' to grasp whether a machine can trick the interrogator into believing it is the other person. The discussion surrounding the debate of the validity of The Turing Test to grasp a machine's intelligence is two-sided, with the test being seen as redundant due to many viewing it as a way to 'test human gullibility' rather than machine intelligence as Gary Marcus states in his Substack article 'AI has (sort of) passed the Turing Test; here's why that hardly matters'. Researching The Turing Test made me realise how intricate the development of AI will be towards ordinary factors of life; the debate surrounding ethical usage of AI in different fields led me to read 'Ethics of Artificial Intelligence and Robotics' in which the concern of data privacy and surveillance with technology discussed. The mention of 'Surveillance being the business model of the Internet' intrigued me with the moral implications of constantly monitoring ordinary civilians and how they use the Internet, especially with the recent establishment of the Online Safety Act by the UK Government. The implications of AI and autonomous tech on different disciplinaries makes me passionate about studying Computer Science.

My selection into the UNIQ program for mathematics allowed me to engage with how Markov Chains can be used to craft an algorithm which behaves like ChatGPT, with repetitive probabilities increasing the likelihood of guessing a predictive answer. Also, the usage of Number theory in cryptography and RSA made me intrigued by the importance of the development of Pure Mathematics to security in Computer Science. I also was selected to be a part of STEM SMART, in which engaging with content for Computer Science, Math, and Further Math by attending weekly meetings and completing tasks helped develop my dedication and interaction with my subjects outside of a school environment. I also took place in the Junior and Senior Maths Challenge, and entered the Caius Explore Competition where I researched databases and the environmental implications they had when AI was brought into their management.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My application for Computer Science is motivated by how broad the field is, with the fascinating but forgotten interplay of policy and technology being a captivating point. The political impact of AI with its mainstream and commercial success, alongside the interwoven impacts AI has on surveillance, education, and community
feedback_items.your_feedback: This first paragraph is absolute nonsense. Saying you want to study computer science because the industry is big is meaningless. The claim that policy and technology interplay is 'forgotten' is wrong - it's extremely relevant today. 'Mainstream and commercial success' just means AI is popular - no academic angle. Then listing surveillance, education, community is like listing colors - you could add 50 other things. The whole paragraph is meaningless.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete the entire first paragraph. Start with 'I read Introduction to Automation and Artificial Intelligence by [author name]'. Get straight into academic content without vague introductions.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My interest in technology stems from my parents' retail job becoming increasingly automated
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a throwaway filler sentence that adds nothing. I don't even know what your parents do or how it was automated specifically. Don't waste characters on this unless you're going to develop it properly later with specific examples.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut this sentence entirely, or if you want to discuss automation in retail, develop it fully: explain the specific automation, discuss what jobs can and cannot be automated, explore what the industry will look like in the future.

feedback_items.weak_passage: the multi-faceted approach companies take towards managing self-sufficient technology with the 'automation spectrum'
feedback_items.your_feedback: This sentence means nothing. What is multi-faceted approach, self-sufficient technology, automation spectrum? I have no idea which companies you're talking about. 'Automation spectrum' is in quotes but it's not a technical term, so it doesn't make sense to use it this way unless you explain it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: When in doubt, ask: Have I been specific? Have I answered every question the reader could have? Define terms, name companies, explain concepts clearly.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This is useful in deciding the risks of automated technology as Professor Parr expresses how development of automated technologies takes place more within the commercial world than the military division
feedback_items.your_feedback: What is 'this'? Are you talking about automation spectrum or multi-faceted approach? Grammatically unclear. You can't bring Professor Parr out of nowhere - you need to say when and how he was talking about this, in what context. Then you suddenly bring in commercial versus military which comes out of left field with this particular introduction.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Introduce Professor Parr properly: 'In a TED Talk, Professor Parr discusses...' Make the logical flow clear. Connect ideas properly rather than jumping topics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In the talk, Christane Fox expresses the huge risk with military technology being unable to discern between 'combatants and civilians' on the battlefield, showing the same issue with autonomous cars struggling to choose between 'pedestrians' and a 'brick wall'
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is an interesting example, but you're approaching it as somebody with general interest, not as a computer science student. You haven't explained any of the actual science behind it. You should explain why it couldn't choose between pedestrian and brick wall - what was wrong with the programming, why AI would never be able to do that, how we could get around this problem, or what academics have said about it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Other students have included these topics but explained the actual computer science behind it. Explain the programming limitations, the algorithmic challenges, the technical constraints that create these ethical dilemmas.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Through my research, I found 'The Turing Test', an article published by Stanford which explores the test made to measure 'human intelligence' within machines
feedback_items.your_feedback: Again, you're just talking about the Turing Test like a person who has an interest in it. You're not talking about any of the science in it or the computer science perspective.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Discuss the technical aspects of the Turing Test - the algorithms, the machine learning approaches, the computational challenges. Show a computer science understanding, not just general interest.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This entire paragraph is samey with no clear point. What are you trying to say? Are you saying AI is damaging? That you want to study AI because it will be used in these industries? Pick a conclusion, pick a strong thesis. I can't pick up what your point is.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Put your point at the very top of the paragraph, then develop it. Talk more from a computer science point of view - how these things are programmed, what the future will look like, any limitations. Have a clear argument.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My selection into the UNIQ program for mathematics allowed me to engage with how Markov Chains can be used to craft an algorithm which behaves like ChatGPT
feedback_items.your_feedback: This Markov chains topic is really interesting but you should have expanded this section and talked more about the math behind it. This could have been your starting point that you levelled up to something university-level and beyond.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand the Markov chains discussion significantly. Explain the mathematical concepts, the algorithmic implementation, how it relates to language models. Make this a centerpiece rather than a mention.

feedback_items.weak_passage: engaging with content for Computer Science, Math, and Further Math by attending weekly meetings and completing tasks helped develop my dedication and interaction with my subjects outside of a school environment. I also took place in the Junior and Senior Maths Challenge
feedback_items.your_feedback: These listy points aren't great. Would prefer if you developed them out more. Also, don't capitalize Maths, Math, Further Math.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either remove these generic activity mentions or develop them with specific examples of problems you solved or concepts you learned.

feedback_items.weak_passage: entered the Caius Explore Competition where I researched databases and the environmental implications they had when AI was brought into their management
feedback_items.your_feedback: Imagine if you had one more sentence. This is the database I looked at. These were the environmental implications. When you're reading the same generic statement over and over, you're crying out for some detail. Somebody else will have an identical sentence, but you could explain with one more sentence and that will be unique to you.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add specific details: which databases, what environmental implications specifically, what you discovered about AI's role in database management. Make it unique and detailed.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You're clearly intelligent and doing well gradewise, but the statement has fundamental problems. There are no theory errors, but there are major issues with logic, writing, structure, and development. You've chosen interesting topics but presented them descriptively without computer science depth. The whole piece lacks a clear argument and technical substance.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Complete rewrite recommended. Start with actual academic content (not vague intro). Pick a thesis and develop it. Explain the computer science behind every topic. Add technical depth throughout. Expand strong sections like Markov chains. Remove the entire first paragraph.

subject: Land Economy
statement_full_text:
Why are you interested in studying this course?
In a world where individuals act irrationally, I am interested in learning how behavioural economics can be further utilised in the policy-making process to address geopolitical problems effectively. This passion originated when I was faced with the challenge of choosing which question to answer for an essay competition. Having already started one but wanting to switch to the other, I realised I was experiencing the theory of loss aversion where the loss of something is greater than the gain, an idea I found prevalent in Richard Thaler's 'Nudge' theory. To further stimulate my intellectual curiosity, I decided to apply the theory on a deeper level after participating in Professor Paul Collier's 'Poverty to Prosperity' course. The issue of informal settlements in low-income cities in place before functioning land markets showed how loss aversion affects path dependence in urban form. With De Facto rights in place for squatters, the perceived loss of their home outweighs the gain of selling it, causing spatial and economic configuration to be locked in. This shows the importance of land markets, as in cities like London it enables central land turnover, however, poorer regions see informal tenure freeze central land, which weakens the agglomeration effect. After doing more research into the environmental law of economics, Coase's theorem of property rights is the conclusion I came to that best explained why some cities, even countries develop faster than others. Without clear rights or land markets, transaction costs are high, hindering the voluntary reallocation of central plots to mixed-use development, stalling the process toward a high connective and productive urban form.

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course?
Completing an EPQ on whether COVID-19 was the main cause for the partial failure of the HS2 allowed me to further explore the blend between Economics and Geography. During my research I began to think of how the uplift in land and property values around the stations would be captured, also thinking of who the winners or losers were. Spatial inequalities were clear throughout the project as I found low-income residents near the station were often displaced, due to a lack of rent controls with luxury developers moving in. Forced into more peripheral areas, I believe such disenfranchisement can lead to a loss of voice in policy making, deepening the 'Geography of Discontent' where communities feel excluded from the benefits of such projects. Theoretically the idea of 'Broken Windows' may prevail, where there is a visible neglect leading to degradation exacerbating spatial inequalities. Taking A-level Economics allowed me not only to apply supply and demand models to the project but helped me evaluate how policies affected individuals. Maths has given me quantitative skills which will help in areas of Econometrics and regression in later life. These skills were useful for a cost-benefit analysis of the project. However, after reading Professor Henry Overman's assessment of the costs and benefits for the Centre for Economic Performance, I would back his argument that we should focus on the opportunity cost rather than CBA as I believe there were better things that could have been done with the funds such as COVID funding. Drama has given me the ability to evaluate and challenge conventional views via political theatre, which is shown through my success in reaching the Finals Day at the University of Oxford's British Parliamentary Debating Competition.

What else have you done outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?
I led an Economics podcast where I analysed how the new Inheritance tax on farmers spurred regional inequalities, arguing that there was a reform paradox as albeit the reform was meant to make tax fairer, differential rent came in where farms on arable land could absorb cost shocks like taxes more than others due to them having more profits as their land was more valuable. Reading Richard Thaler's 'Economics of Social Problems', substantiated my argument that Housing should not be left to the market due to Imperfect Information. Minorities such as immigrants in urban areas may not have sufficient time to be fully educated on the housing system, preventing them from living in its narrowly defined areas. I find both experiences useful as they have allowed me to see how friction between markets happens in the real world.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall good job - you clearly have done a lot of work and know a lot. The content is interesting and you've chosen good topics. However, there are parts that aren't doing as good a job as you think. Main issues are logical flow, sentence structure, and some weak points that need development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on improving logical flow between ideas, simplifying overly complex sentences, and fleshing out the weaker arguments. The first paragraph needs the most work on structure and clarity.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In a world where individuals act irrationally, I am interested in learning how behavioural economics can be further utilised in the policy-making process to address geopolitical problems effectively
feedback_items.your_feedback: This entire first sentence is weak. It makes it seem like everyone behaves irrationally all the time, which isn't true. You say 'further utilised' but you haven't said how it's utilised in the first place, so 'further' doesn't make sense. The whole thing is very vague and comes out of nowhere - not a strong start.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this opening sentence entirely. Start with something like: 'I came across the idea of loss aversion whilst reading Thaler's Nudge' or go straight into the essay competition story with loss aversion.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This passion originated when I was faced with the challenge of choosing which question to answer for an essay competition. Having already started one but wanting to switch to the other, I realised I was experiencing the theory of loss aversion
feedback_items.your_feedback: This part is confusing. The flow from passion to essay competition to loss aversion to poverty course is muddled and hard to follow.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Restructure to: Start with reading Thaler's Nudge and loss aversion. Give a brief everyday example like the essay competition. Then naturally lead into Paul Collier's course and the informal settlements application. This creates clearer logical flow.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Coase's theorem of property rights is the conclusion I came to that best explained why some cities, even countries develop faster than others. Without clear rights or land markets, transaction costs are high
feedback_items.your_feedback: You can't present Coase's theorem as 'the conclusion I came to'. You can explain the theorem, link it to your point, and explain one interesting conclusion, but doing it this way makes it seem like you haven't understood it correctly.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reframe as: 'I also came across Coase's theorem of property rights. I believe this explains the variation in rates of development between cities and countries.' Then explain the theorem and link it properly to your point.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You write quite lengthy sentences throughout. For example: 'After doing more research into the environmental law of economics, Coase's theorem of property rights is the conclusion I came to that best explain why some cities, even countries, develop faster than others.' This is too long and reads backwards. Simplify your sentence structure.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Use shorter, clearer sentences. Start with the main point, then develop. Instead of 'After doing X, Y is the conclusion', try 'I came across Y. This explains X.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: Completing an EPQ on whether COVID-19 was the main cause for the partial failure of the HS2 allowed me to further explore the blend between Economics and Geography. During my research I began to think of how the uplift in land and property values around the stations would be captured
feedback_items.your_feedback: Don't capitalize Economics and Geography when referencing subjects. Also needs better punctuation - 'During my research, comma, I began to think...'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Fix capitalization and add proper punctuation throughout. Start with shorter sentences, then build to longer ones for better readability.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This EPQ section is interesting and fairly well-developed. The content is good and shows clear thinking about spatial inequalities and economic impacts.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Just minor grammar fixes needed - the content itself is strong.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Completing an EPQ on whether COVID-19 was the main cause for the partial failure of the HS2...During my research I began to think of how the uplift in land and property values around the stations would be captured, also thinking of who the winners or losers were. Spatial inequalities were clear throughout the project
feedback_items.why_strong: This section works well because you have something specific to discuss and you develop it properly. When you focus on concrete examples, your analysis is strong and clear.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Taking A-level Economics allowed me not only to apply supply and demand models to the project but helped me evaluate how policies affected individuals. Maths has given me quantitative skills which will help in areas of Econometrics and regression
feedback_items.your_feedback: You can't just say you applied supply and demand models - that doesn't mean anything, like saying 'I applied numbers to a math problem'. Tell me exactly how you applied the models, in what context. When you mention quantitative skills for econometrics and regression, you can't just name-drop. Give an example.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain: How did you specifically apply supply and demand models to HS2? What regressions did you actually run for your EPQ? What was one particular interesting problem in econometrics? Show proof of understanding, not just claims.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I would back his argument that we should focus on the opportunity cost rather than CBA as I believe there were better things that could have been done with the funds such as COVID funding
feedback_items.your_feedback: Don't say 'back his argument' - just say 'I agree'. The point about focusing on opportunity cost over CBA is fairly weak and oversimplified - it's not that simple. Even though your EPQ is interesting, this conclusion feels underdeveloped.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either develop this argument more thoroughly with economic reasoning, or present it differently without oversimplifying the CBA versus opportunity cost debate.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Drama has given me the ability to evaluate and challenge conventional views via political theatre, which is shown through my success in reaching the Finals Day at the University of Oxford's British Parliamentary Debating Competition
feedback_items.your_feedback: You probably won't have enough space to include this in the real thing. If you do have space, consider moving this to the last question instead where it fits better with extracurriculars.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Move to paragraph 3 or remove if space is tight. Prioritize academic content over this.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I led an Economics podcast where I analysed how the new Inheritance tax on farmers spurred regional inequalities, arguing that there was a reform paradox as albeit the reform was meant to make tax fairer, differential rent came in where farms on arable land could absorb cost shocks
feedback_items.your_feedback: Please, please rewrite this sentence. It is so confusing to get through. The structure makes it very difficult to understand your point about the reform paradox and differential rent.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Break this into multiple shorter sentences. Explain the inheritance tax reform first, then the paradox, then differential rent separately. Make each concept clear before moving to the next.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Reading Richard Thaler's 'Economics of Social Problems', substantiated my argument that Housing should not be left to the market due to Imperfect Information. Minorities such as immigrants in urban areas may not have sufficient time to be fully educated on the housing system
feedback_items.your_feedback: Random capitalizations throughout (Housing, Imperfect Information shouldn't be capitalized). The point about minorities and immigrants feels thrown in and not fully fleshed out or developed. It would fit better in question 2 when discussing housing and property, or could be a new point in question 1 if you cut that first paragraph in half.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either move this Thaler discussion to question 2 where you already discuss housing and property, or develop it much more fully if keeping it here. Fix all capitalizations. Consider whether the drama section should go at the end of paragraph 3 instead.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Summary of needed changes: First paragraph needs cutting in half - improve logical flow and rework Coase section. Question 2 is pretty good but needs the A-level metrics section fleshed out and sentence structure improved. Third paragraph needs drama moved to the end, potentially cut or move the Economics of Social Problems section, and critically rewrite that first sentence about inheritance tax.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: The first paragraph could be cut to 50% and you'd have space for an entire new point. Focus on making arguments clearer and more economic (less political). Strengthen technical explanations throughout, especially around econometrics and models.
